title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Fearful of AI-generated grant proposals, NIH limits scientists to six applications per year
items.description: Some critics of the new policy say the cap could hinder researchers in need of funding

items.title: U.S. research community says new indirect cost model is still too complicated
items.description: Proposed changes to avert huge cuts in reimbursement get pushback at town hall

items.title: Why do some moms have more boys than girls—or vice versa? New study provides clues
items.description: Researchers find that certain genetic variants and mother’s age may have an impact on the sex of her children

items.title: A new kind of telescope is set to search for mysterious fast radio bursts
items.description: Radio telescopes usually have giant dishes, but not these all-sky antenna arrays

items.title: Senate panel raises hopes that NSF will restore killed grants
items.description: Republicans promise to work with Democrats to salvage defeated amendment

items.title: How a string of deadly shark attacks made a remote island a hub of lifesaving research
items.description: After 11 deaths, Réunion Island in the Indian Ocean became a center for shark attack science

items.title: Google alerts offer quick, cheap earthquake warnings
items.description: In 3 years, system embedded in Android phones sent warnings to millions of users in 98 countries

items.title: Europe plans to double research spending in next Horizon Europe scheme
items.description: Starting in 2028, the EU’s flagship research program will have a new focus on boosting European competitiveness

items.title: Russian scientists’ international collaborations to be vetted by security services under new law
items.description: Move will have a chilling effect and further isolate the country from the global scientific community, researchers say

items.title: New transplant techniques keep organ donors’ hearts healthy—even after they stop beating
items.description: Strategies for preserving the heart after circulation stops could avoid ethical concerns and enable more transplants
